The ready idle measurement for the highest predicted deployed storage device optimal point in GB per watt.
The ratio of installed storage devices with addressable storage (not used for cache) during testing of the highest predicted deployed device(s) optimal point.  If there is more than one device in the highest predicted deployed storage device, the ratio of each storage device is separated by a semicolon.
The data for the storage device 1 optimal point is obtained by physically testing the system or through the use of modeled data.  Storage device 1 is the first device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The rated speed of storage device 1 in RPM.  Storage device 1 is the first device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
If automated storage tiering (auto-tiering) was enabled during testing of the highest predicted deployed device(s) optimal point.
The ready idle measurement for storage device 2 optimal point in GB per watt.  Storage device 2 is the second device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The devices used for cache are identified here.  This can be DRAM, SSD, or Other device.
The raw capacity of storage device 2 in GB.  Storage device 2 is the second device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The form factor of storage device 1 is either 2.5 inch, 3.5 inch, or Other.  Storage device 1 is the first device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The sequential read measurement for the highest predicted deployed storage device optimal point in MiB Per Second (MiBPS) per watt.
If Other was chosen for Trans Device Used for Cache, the type of Other device is identified here.
A configuration provided by the manufacturer may be optimized for the following workload types: transaction, streaming, or capacity.  Transaction is a workload type optimized for random I/O usage measured in I/O per second per watt.  Streaming is a workload type optimized primarily for sequential I/O usage, measured in MiB per second per watt.  Capacity is a workload type optimized for maximum storage as measured by GB (Raw Capacity) per watt.
Advanced Data Recovery Capability is a collective term used in this specification to refer to error detection and correction features such as RAID, mirroring / grid technology, or other comparable advanced error detection and recovery systems.
The random write measurement for storage device 1 optimal point in I/O Per Second (IOPS) per watt.  Storage device 1 is the first device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The form factor of storage device 2 is either 2.5 inch, 3.5 inch, or Other.  Storage device 2 is the second device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
If automated storage tiering (auto-tiering) was enabled during testing of the storage device 1.  Storage device 1 is the first device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The total number of PSUs installed during testing of the highest predicted deployed device(s) optimal point.
The number of devices installed in storage device 1 optimal point.  Storage device 1 is the first device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The random write measurement for storage device 2 optimal point in I/O Per Second (IOPS) per watt.  Storage device 2 is the second device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
If automated storage tiering (auto-tiering) was enabled during testing of the highest predicted deployed device(s) optimal point.
The random read measurement for storage device 2 optimal point in I/O Per Second (IOPS) per watt.  Storage device 2 is the second device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device. 
The type of storage device can be either a Hard Disk Drive (HDD) or a Solid State Drive (SSD).  Storage device 1 is the first device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The hot band measurement for storage device 2 optimal point in I/O Per Second (IOPS) per watt.  Storage device 2 is the second device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The random read measurement for the highest predicted deployed storage device optimal point in IOPS per watt.
The Rated Output per installed PSU in watts.  If there is more than one power supply, each power supply's rated output will be separated by a semicolon.
The ratio of installed storage devices with addressable storage (not used for cache) during testing of the highest predicted deployed device(s) optimal point.  If there is more than one device in the highest predicted deployed storage device, the ratio of each storage device is separated by a semicolon.
The SNIA Taxonomy is a categorization scheme for use in segmenting the data center storage market by end-use application and key product characteristics.  The three categories eligible for ENERGY STAR certification are Online 2, Online 3, and Online 4.
The 80PLUS certification level achieved by the PSU(s) installed.  If there is more than one power supply, each power supply's certification level will be separated by a semicolon.
The total number of redundant controllers installed during testing of the highest predicted deployed device(s) optimal point.
The type of storage device can be either a Hard Disk Drive (HDD) or a Solid State Drive (SSD).  Storage device 2 is the second device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
The raw capacity of storage device 2 in GB.  Storage device 2 is the second device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The data for the storage device 2 optimal point is obtained by physically testing the system or through the use of modeled data.  Storage device 2 is the second device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to the PSU(s) for sales and marketing purposes.  If there is more than one power supply, each power supply's model name will be separated by a semicolon.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to the model or configuration by the manufacturer or private labeler.  Stream indicates that this information is for the Streaming Workload Optimization Type.
The ready idle measurement for the highest predicted deployed storage device optimal point in GB per watt.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to the PSU(s) for sales and marketing purposes.  If there is more than one power supply, each power supply's model name will be separated by a semicolon.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
The type(s) of power supply unit(s) installed.  A Power Supply Unit (PSU) is a device that converts ac or dc input power to one or more dc power outputs for the purpose of powering a storage product. A storage PSU must be self-contained and physically separable from the system and must connect to the system via a removable or hard-wired electrical connection.  If there is more than one power supply, each power supply's type will be separated by a semicolon.
The random write measurement for the highest predicted deployed storage device optimal point in IOPS per watt.
The total amount of cache available in GB.  Cache is temporary storage used to transparently store transitory data and which is not directly addressable by end-user applications. Primarily used for expediting access to or from (typically) slower devices.
The form factor of storage device 1 is either 2.5 inch, 3.5 inch, or Other.  Storage device 1 is the first device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The total number of redundant PSUs installed during testing of the highest predicted deployed device(s) optimal point.
The devices used for cache are identified here.  This can be DRAM, SSD, or Other device.
If configuration(s) is/are capable of calculating an inlet air temperature, the length of the rolling average is provided here.
The rated speed of storage device 2 in RPM.  Storage device 2 is the second device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The total number of Solid State Devices installed during testing of the highest predicted deployed device(s) optimal point.  If there is more than one device in the highest predicted deployed storage device, each device's number of solid state drives is separated by a semicolon. 
The total number of redundant controllers installed during testing of the highest predicted deployed device(s) optimal point.
If Other was chosen for Trans Device Used for Cache, the type of Other device is identified here.
If configuration(s) is/are capable of calculating an input power rolling average, the length of the rolling average is provided here.
Automated Storage Tiering is the automatic movement of data between different types of storage devices. Tiering may occur within a single storage product or may span multiple storage products. For the purposes of ENERGY STAR certification, only tiering within a single storage product is applicable.
The sequential write measurement for storage device 1 optimal point in MiB Per Second (MiBPS) per watt.  Storage device 1 is the first device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

The total number of controllers installed during testing of the highest predicted deployed device(s) optimal point.
The ready idle measurement for storage device 1 optimal point in GB per watt.  Storage device 1 is the first device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The manufacturer of the installed PSU(s).  If there is more than one power supply, each power supply's manufacturer name will be separated by a semicolon.
The sequential write measurement for the highest predicted deployed storage device optimal point in MiB Per Second (MiBPS) per watt.
The number of devices installed in storage device 1 optimal point.  Storage device 1 is the first device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.
If automated storage tiering (auto-tiering) was enabled during testing of the storage device 2.  Storage device 2 is the second device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The total number of redundant PSUs installed during testing of the highest predicted deployed device(s) optimal point.
The hot band measurement for storage device 1 optimal point in I/O Per Second (IOPS) per watt.  Storage device 1 is the first device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The data for the storage device 2 optimal point is obtained by physically testing the system or through the use of modeled data.  Storage device 2 is the second device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The sequential read measurement for storage device 1 optimal point in MiB Per Second (MiBPS) per watt.  Storage device 1 is the first device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The Rated Output per installed PSU in watts.  If there is more than one power supply, each power supply's rated output will be separated by a semicolon.
The type(s) of power supply unit(s) installed.  A Power Supply Unit (PSU) is a device that converts ac or dc input power to one or more dc power outputs for the purpose of powering a storage product. A storage PSU must be self-contained and physically separable from the system and must connect to the system via a removable or hard-wired electrical connection.  If there is more than one power supply, each power supply's type will be separated by a semicolon.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. This column includes alternative means to identify the model/model family (e.g., additional model names, additional model numbers, retailer SKUs, product descriptions).
The ready idle measurement for storage device 2 optimal point in GB per watt.  Storage device 2 is the second device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The total number of rotational devices installed during testing of the highest predicted deployed device(s) optimal point.  If there is more than one device in the highest predicted deployed storage device, each device's number of rotational drives is separated by a semicolon.
A storage controller can be implemented in two different ways.  Scale-up storage is a storage product comprised of a discreet storage controller (with or without redundancy), which has a full view of all the storage devices in the storage product. Incremental storage capacity is added by the addition of storage devices under the control of the existing storage controller.  While Scale-out storage is a storage product capable of being comprised of two or more discreet storage controllers (with or without redundancy), combined with an overall integration or aggregation function resulting in a single storage product view for attached servers. Each discreet storage controller often has a partial view to a partition of the overall system's storage devices, but this is not a fixed requirement. Incremental storage capacity is added by the addition of storage devices under the control of the existing storage controller(s) and/or addition of additional storage devices along with additional controller(s).
The raw capacity of storage device 1 in GB.  Storage device 1 is the first device in addition to the highest predicted deployed storage device.
The total number of PSUs installed during testing of the highest predicted deployed device(s) optimal point.
The hot band measurement for the highest predicted deployed storage device optimal point in I/O Per Second (IOPS) per watt.
The total number of rotational devices installed during testing of the highest predicted deployed device(s) optimal point.  If there is more than one device in the highest predicted deployed storage device, each device's number of rotational drives is separated by a semicolon.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Ceiling Fans Light Kits
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 2.0, 2.1 or 2.2 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Luminaires that are effective as of June 1, 2016 and Version 4.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Ceiling Fans that are effective as of June 15, 2018. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/lighting_fans/ceiling_fans/ceiling_fans_key_product_criteria
columns_name: Lighting Efficiency – Measured outside the Fixture (lm/W)
Lighting Efficiency – Measured at the Source (lm/W)
columns_description: This column indicates whether the ceiling fan light kit is intended for indoor use only or can be used outdoors.
Light sources can be fully integrated into a light kit or removable by a consumer by custom connectors, wire nuts, pronged plugs like GU10, GU24 or sockets e.g. E26 known as the Edison base.
The light source technology utilized by the fixture: compact fluorescent light (CFL) or light emitting diode (LED).

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as the ability to turn off the unit remotely when not at home and feedback on the energy use of the product. Connected functionality is optional and ceiling fan light kits may be certified without it.
Provides guidance about what you need in your home to enable connected capabilities like smart phone control (e.g., Wi-Fi or ZigBee).
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

A description of the "color" of a light source measured on the Kelvin (K) scale. CFLs are available in a range of color temperatures. Lower values (2700-3000K) mean the white light has a warmer (red-yellow) tone, while higher kelvin (4100-6500K) mean the white light has a cooler (bluer) tone.
This column indicates whether the ceiling fan light kit is shipped with ENERGY STAR certified lamps.

The expected useful life of the light source. Measured differently depending on the technology of the light source. For example, LED lighting expected useful life is based on the estimated point at which only 70% of the original light output remains, while for older technologies, like fluorescent, estimated useful life is based on the measured median sample life.

Ratio of real power flowing to the light source to the apparent power in the circuit. A lamp with a lower power factor will draw more current than a lamp with a higher power factor of the same wattage.
This column indicates alternate ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) number(s) for the ENERGY STAR lamps that are shipped with the certified ceiling fan light kit.
This column indicates the ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) number for the ENERGY STAR lamps that are shipped with the certified ceiling fan light kit.

Certified ceiling fan light kits with replaceable drivers shall provide a warranty of at least 3 years. Certified ceiling fan light kits with non-replaceable drivers shall provide a warranty of at least 5 years.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. This model number pertains only to the lamp.
The quotient of the total luminous flux (lumens) emitted by the fixture over the total power input (Watts). It is expressed in lumens per watt (lm/W).

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.
Total power consumed by the light kit (luminaire) while in use.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.

This column includes for the certified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

The amount of light emitted by the light source or light fixture. Fixtures with removable light sources are measured at the light source and do not account for light lost from the fixture, while other fixtures, where the light source cannot be removed, are measured at the fixture level, only counting the light that escapes the fixture. Ceiling fan light kits shipped with ENERGY STAR Lamps do not have to meet minimum light output requirements.

The Color Rendering Index (CRI) of a light source represents the degree of color shift objects undergo when illuminated by the light source as compared with the color of those same objects when illuminated by a reference source of comparable color temperature. The ENERGY STAR specifications require a CRI of at least 80. Incandescent lighting has a CRI of 100. Early fluorescent lighting had CRIs in the 60s, resulting in unpleasant appearance of skin tones.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR certified products.

Most light kits are designed to operate on an on/off switch. However, some have been designed with additional or advanced features (e.g. dimmability, remote control,  and motion sensors). Special features and compatibility with controls should be clearly marked on the product packaging, cut sheet or web site for the product.
Indicates information on certification relevant to the consumer (i.e. product variations, unique issues concerning the model’s listing, etc.).

These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient
The date that the model is available for purchase.

Combined Energy Efficiency Ratio (CEER) is an energy performance metric for room air conditioners, as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix F. The higher the CEER, the more efficient the room air conditioner. The metric has units Btu/Wh, and is calculated as the quotient of the cooling capacity divided by the average rate of electrical energy consumed by the air conditioner during operational and non-operational modes.

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as the ability to turn off the unit remotely when not at home and feedback on the energy use of the product. Room air conditioners with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill.
An external communication module or device is required if communication hardware is not built into the unit.

Connected appliances may or may not enable open-standards connectivity in the home. Consider the following illustrative examples: "Yes" An appliance that can directly communicate using Wi-Fi and OpenADR, or wired Ethernet and SEP 2.x; "No" An appliance that uses proprietary communications to/from the cloud, and is capable of supporting open-standards communications only in the cloud.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower-GWP alternative refrigerant options for room air conditioners include R-32, R-454B, R-290, R-600a, R-441A, R-452B, R-454A, R-454C, and R-457A.
Average power consumption of the unit when in automatic sleep mode.

The cooling capacity of the room air conditioner, in Btu (British Thermal Units) per hour, as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix F. A higher Btu/hr means the product offers a greater cooling capability.
Classification of products by the type of energy used or by capacity or other performance-related features that affect efficiency. Different ENERGY STAR levels may apply to different product classes.

This number is the estimated annual energy use in kilowatt hours per year of the room air conditioner under typical conditions. This figure assumes 750 hours of compressor operation per year but will vary depending on the indoor and outdoor temperature and hours of use.

The ENERGY STAR room air conditioner criteria covers both the casement-only and casement-slider product classes. Casement-only refers to a room air conditioner designed for mounting in a casement window. Casement-slider refers to a room air conditioner with an encased assembly designed for mounting in a sliding or casement window.
The weight of the room air conditioner, not including packaging, in lbs (pounds).

Room air conditioners with variable speed compressors are able to save a significant amount of energy during operation by continuously and quietly regulating the temperature. Room air conditioners with conventional compressors are either operating at maximum capacity when the thermostat calls for cooling or off when the desired temperature has been achieved and typically alternating frequently between on at maximum capacity and off.

Room air conditioners with louvered sides are designed for mounting in a window, while units without louvered sides (also commonly referred to as "built-in") are designed for mounting through the wall of a building.

CAafue: The Combined Appliance Annual Fuel Utilization Efficiency (“CAafue”) is the effective efficiency of the combined appliance in performing the function of space heating.

The Heating Seasonal Performance Factor (HSPF2) is the total heating output of a central air-conditioning heat pump during its normal annual usage period for heating, expressed in Btus and divided by the total electric power input, expressed in Btu/Wh using  10 CFR part 430, Subpart B, Appendix M1 – Section 3.6 Heating mode tests for Different Types of Heat Pumps, Including Heating-Only Heat Pumps.

A Single Package unit is any central air conditioner that has all major assemblies enclosed in one cabinet. A Split System is any central air conditioner that has two separate assemblies, including an indoor coil and an outdoor coil.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.

Indicates whether the model meets optional connected criteria as defined in the specification, which may include functions helpful to the electrical grid (standardized signals and responses to manage energy use) and those helpful to consumers, such as scheduling and energy reporting.
Indicates product model is eligible for federal income tax credits available under the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient

A system manufacturer manufactures all the major assemblies in an air-source heat pump and/or central air-conditioner. An independent coil manufacturer (ICM) manufactures only the indoor unit (coil) in a central air conditioner or air-source heat pump split system.
The Hardware Architecture describes the type of module/device within or external to the system needed for connection.
Indicates the type of refrigerant used in the model.

Indicates heat pumps that meet the ENERGY STAR cold climate criteria; cold climate heat pumps will provide better heating performance in low ambient temperatures, making these products an excellent choice for cold climate installations where the heat pump will be the sole heating source.
Meets EER2 requirements for efficient cooling at 95F.
Indicates whether the compressors supports changing heating and cooling capacity: single stage, two stages, more two stages, continuously variable.
This is the manufacturer of the outdoor unit for combinations that include indoor units from Independent Coil Manufacturers.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
Indicates which standardized protocol is used to send load management messages to the unit.
Features enabled by external communication modules/devices allow the system to provide user control and monitoring and act on external commands delivered remotely.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

The Seasonal Energy Efficiency Ratio (SEER2) is the ratio of the total heat removed from the conditioned space during the annual cooling season to the total electrical energy consumed by the air conditioner or heat pump during the same season, expressed in Btu/Wh using 10 CFR part 430, Subpart B, Appendix M1 – Section 3.6 Heating mode tests for Different Types of Heat Pumps, Including Heating-Only Heat Pumps.

The Energy Efficiency Ratio (EER2) is the ratio of the produced cooling effect of an air conditioner or heat pump to its net work input, expressed in Btu/watt-hour using 10 CFR part 430, Subpart B, Appendix M1 – Section 3.6 Heating mode tests for Different Types of Heat Pumps, Including Heating-Only Heat Pumps.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
This list/dataset includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

Capabilities identified to aid installers, some of which only apply to centrally ducted systems. These may include 1) Refrigerant charge verification, 2) Airflow measurement or external static pressure, 3) Blower fan power draw, 4) Test mode for manual measurements, 5) Automatic system discovery, and/or 6) Preprogrammed system tests.

For independent coil manufacturers (ICMs), this is the manufacturer of the outdoor unit used with the independent coil. For system manufacturers, the indoor and outdoor manufacturer is the ENERGY STAR Partner.
An external communication module or device is required if communication hardware is not built into the unit.
Central air conditioners or heat pumps without an integrated blower fan will be tested with a furnace. Products are only ENERGY STAR certified in combination with the listed furnace.
System can communicate using these protocols for sending messages and requests, some of which work wirelessly and some with wires (open standard media/network layer).

Energy Efficiency - Measured Outside the Fixture (lm/W)
Bathroom and Utility Room Airflow at 0.25 in. w.g.
Meets ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2024 Criteria
columns_description: A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. This model number pertains only to the lamp.

An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
Residential bath and utility ventilating fans and range hoods must meet maximum allowable sound levels between 2-3 sones. There are no sound requirements for single or multi-port in-line fans.
This measurement showcases the sound performance of a fan that is installed and operating under a heavier load than it is designed for.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
This column indicates alternate ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) number(s) for the ENERGY STAR lamps that are shipped with the certified ventilating fan.
This column indicates the ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) number for the ENERGY STAR lamps that are shipped with the certified ceiling fan.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
Ratio of real power flowing to the lamp to the apparent power in the circuit. A lamp with a lower power factor will draw more current than a lamp with a higher power factor of the same wattage.
For ventilating fans with lighting, this column indicates whether the ceiling fan is shipped with ENERGY STAR certified lamps.

The amount of light emitted by the light source or light fixture. Non directional fixtures (with removable light sources i.e. GU24 base bulbs) are measured at the light source and do not account for light lost from the fixture, while other fixtures meant to put light on a specific application (e.g. recessed downlights, under cabinet lights, accent lights, cove lights) are measured at the fixture level, only counting the light that escapes the fixture.
The light source technology utilized by the fixture: compact fluorescent light (CFL), light emitting diode (LED), or halogen.

The quotient of the total luminous flux (lumens) emitted by the fixture over the total power input (Watts). It is expressed in lumens per watt (lm/W). For ENERGY STAR qualified fixtures this applies to light fixtures that are considered directional and are measured at the fixture level. This includes the following residential grade directional fixture types: line-voltage track lights, ceiling fan light kits, undercabinet and cove lighting, downlights, recessed, pendant or surface mounted and includes retrofit kits for existing recessed cans. This also includes the following LIMITED commercial fixture types: Accent lights such as line-voltage track lights, under cabinet task lights, portable desk task lights, downlights, recessed, pendant or surface-mounts BUT EXCLUDES typical commercial and industrial fixtures such as recessed troffers or linear forms (e.g. linear fluorescent pendants) typically used in office spaces.

It is standard industry practice to round down airflow to the nearest 10 cfm when publishing this metric in product directories as the Airflow Certified Rating. For this reason, Airflow Certified Rating and As-Tested Airflow may occasionally differ on this list. In the case of a range hood, Airflow Certified Rating represents performance at working speed, while in the case of a bathroom or utility room fan, or an in-line ventilating fan, it represents maximum speed.
The number of speeds available for a ventilating fan. For fans with three or more speeds, only 3 is displayed.
This measurement showcases the airflow performance of a fan that is installed and operating under a heavier load than it is designed for.

The expected useful life of the light source. Measured differently depending on the technology of the light source. For example, LED lighting expected useful life is based on the estimated point at which only 70% of the original light output remains, while for older technologies, like fluorescent and halogen, estimated useful life is based on the measured median sample life.

It is standard industry practice to round down airflow to the nearest 10 cfm when publishing this metric in product directories as the Airflow Certified Rating. For this reason, Airflow Certified Rating and As-Tested Airflow may occasionally differ on this list. In the case of a range hood, Airflow Certified Rating represents performance at working speed, while in the case of a bathroom or utility room fan, or an in-line ventilating fan, it represents maximum speed.
Indicates information on certification relevant to the consumer (i.e. product variations, unique issues concerning the model’s listing, etc.).

Most fixtures are designed to operate on an on/off switch. However, some fixtures have been designed with features to perform in specialized applications, such as with dimmers, three-way, or photo cell controls. Special features and compatibility with controls should be clearly marked on the product packaging, cut sheet or web site for the product.

Efficacy is calculated by using airflow and fan motor electrical power values as tested per the requirements of this specification. Fan motor electrical usage is the only energy consumption considered for the fan efficacy calculation. Energy used for other fan auxiliaries (e.g., lights, sensors, heaters, timers, or night lights) is not included in the determination of fan efficacy.
Duct size indicates circular diameter for circular ducts and depth by width for rectangular ducts.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
Some in-line fans are shipped with a filter. The minimum efficiency reporting value (MERV) rating indicates the level of filtration. A higher MERV rating means a greater level of filtration.

Measure of the degree of color shift objects undergo when illuminated by the light source as compared with the color of those same objects when illuminated by a reference source of comparable color temperature.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.

Indicates if the unit includes a light source.
Total power consumed by the luminaire while in use.

A description of the "color" of a light source measured on the Kelvin (K) scale. CFLs are available in a range of color temperatures. Lower values (2700-3000K) mean the white light has a warmer (red-yellow) tone, while higher kelvin (4100-6500K) mean the white light has a cooler (bluer) tone.

Fan motor electrical usage is the only energy consumption considered for the fan efficacy calculation. Energy used for other fan auxiliaries (e.g., lights, sensors, heaters, timers, or night lights) is not included in the determination of fan efficacy.

A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/appliances/refrigerators/key_product_criteria
columns_name: Percent Less Energy Use than US Federal Standard
Meets ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2024 Criteria
columns_description:

seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification

bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower-GWP alternative refrigerant options for residential freezers include R-600a and R-441A.
The total interior volume of the freezer. Generally, the larger the freezer, the greater the energy consumption.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
ENERGY STAR certified residential freezers must generally exceed the U.S. federal standard by at least 10%. This column tells you by how much each model exceeds the standard.

Freezers are available in both chest and upright configurations. An upright freezer has a front-mounted door like a refrigerator and shelves that allow for easy organization. A chest freezer typically requires more floor space, but they are also more energy efficient and since the door opens from the top it will allow less cold air to escape.

This number is the estimated annual energy use in kilowatt hours of the freezer under typical conditions. Your actual energy consumption will vary depending on how you use your freezer, such as frequency of opening and closing, surrounding room temperature, and how full the unit is kept. This figure is calculated according to U.S. Department of Energy test procedures.
Designation for freezers with a total volume of less than 7.75 cubic feet and 36 inches or less in height.
Built-in freezers are designed to be installed totally encased by kitchen cabinets.

Freezers are available with either manual or automatic defrost. Manual defrost freezers use about half the energy of automatic defrost models, but must be defrosted periodically to achieve the energy savings. Don’t allow frost to build up more than one quarter of an inch.

Indicates if the model has the through-the-door ice feature. It does not indicate whether or not the model has an ice maker. Please contact the manufacturer directly to determine if the model has an ice maker.
Included in some refrigerators for making ice cubes.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as sending notifications when the freezer door is not closed or allowing for a service center to remotely diagnose problems. Freezers with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The U.S. federal standard is the maximum energy consumption in kWh/year allowed by the U.S. Department of Energy for a freezer of this particular configuration and size.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient
Indicates the type of refrigerant used in the model.

This is a figure accounting for the fact that freezers require more energy than refrigerators per unit of actual volume, because they are colder. The adjusted volume is the sum of the fresh food compartment volume and the product of an adjustment factor and the net freezer compartment volume in cubic feet. It's used to determine the federal energy conservation standards for refrigerators and freezers. Refrigerator Adjusted Volume = Fresh Volume + (1.63 x Freezer Volume). Freezer Adjusted Volume = 1.73 x Freezer Volume.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
Classification of products by the type of energy used or by capacity or other performance-related features that affect efficiency. Different ENERGY STAR levels may apply to different product classes.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Commercial Clothes Washers
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 8.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Clothes Washers that are effective as of February 5, 2018. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/appliances/clothes_washers/key_product_criteria.
columns_description: The mandatory water efficiency standards for clothes washers, established by DOE rulemaking activities and federal laws.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

IWF is the water performance metric for ENERGY STAR certified clothes washers. The lower the IWF, the more efficient the clothes washer. The metric has units: gallons/cycle/ft3, and is calculated as the quotient of total weighted per-cycle water consumption divided by the capacity of the clothes washer. For example, if a clothes washer has a total weighted per-cycle water consumption of 20 gallons and a tub volume of 4.0 cubic feet, then the IWF is 5.0.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
Type refers to whether the product is a front-loading washer or a top-loading washer.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

WF is the water performance metric for ENERGY STAR qualified clothes washers. The lower the WF, the more efficient the clothes washer. The metric has units: gallons/cycle/ft3, and is calculated as the quotient of total weighted per-cycle water consumption divided by the capacity of the clothes washer. For example, if a clothes washer has a total weighted per-cycle water consumption of 20 gallons and a tub volume of 4.0 cubic feet, then the water factor is 5.0.
The mandatory water efficiency standards for clothes washers, established by DOE rule-making activities and federal laws.
This refers to whether the product is intended to be sold in the residential market, the commercial/multi-family housing/coin laundry market, or both.
The mandatory energy efficiency standards for clothes washers, established by DOE rulemaking activities and federal laws.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

This is the estimated annual energy use of the clothes washer under typical conditions, including the energy used by the washer and the energy needed to heat the water used by the clothes washer with an electric water heater. Unlike MEF, the estimated annual energy use does not address how effective the washer is at removing moisture from the wash load and thus reducing the energy needed to fully dry a load in the clothes dryer. It is based on an annual usage of 1,074 loads per year for multi-family and 1,483 loads per year for laundromat applications, or around 21 and 29 loads per week respectively, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J2. Actual energy consumption will vary depending on various factors such as the amount of laundry done, the size of the loads, and the settings chosen.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.

MEF is the energy performance metric for ENERGY STAR certified commercial clothes washers. The higher the MEF, the more energy efficient the clothes washer. The metric has units: ft3/kWh/cycle, and is calculated as the quotient of the capacity of the clothes container divided by the total clothes washer energy consumption per cycle, with such energy consumption expressed as the sum of the machine electrical energy consumption, the hot water energy consumption, and the energy required for removal of the remaining moisture in the wash load. For example, if a clothes washer has a tub volume of 4.0 cubic feet and a total clothes washer energy consumption per cycle of 10 kWh/cycle, then the MEF is 2.5.
Features applicable to the clothes washer may include Steam Cycle, Anti-Wrinkle, Gentle Cycle, Delayed Start, Sanitize Option, Hand Wash Cycle, and Supplementary Wash System.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
This is the tub capacity of the clothes washer in cubic feet, as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J2.
A Universal Product Code (UPC) is a specific type of barcode for tracking items sold in stores.

characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

A geothermal heat pump uses the thermal energy of the ground or groundwater to provide residential space conditioning and/or domestic water heating. A geothermal heat pump model normally consists of one or more factory-made assemblies that include indoor conditioning and/or domestic water heat exchanger(s), compressors, and a ground-side heat exchanger. A geothermal heat pump model may provide space heating, space cooling, domestic water heating, or a combination of these functions and may also include the functions of liquid circulation, thermal storage, air circulation, air cleaning, dehumidifying or humidifying. A geothermal heat pump system generally consists of one or more geothermal heat pump models, the ground heat exchanger(s), the air and/or hydronic space conditioning distribution system(s), temperature controls, and thermal storage tanks.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient

ENERGY STAR specification.

columns_description: CEF is the energy performance metric for ENERGY STAR clothes dryers; the higher the CEF the more efficient the clothes dryer. The metric has units lbs/kWh and is calculated by dividing the weight of the test load by the sum of the per cycle standby and off mode energy consumption and either the total per-cycle electricity dryer energy consumption or the total per-cycle gas dryer energy consumption expressed in kilowatt hours (kWh).
This is the tub capacity of the clothes washer in cubic feet, as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J2.

For combination all-in-one washer-dryers, the estimated energy test cycle time is the time taken to complete the test cycle necessary for ENERGY STAR certification. Products must complete the energy test cycle in less than 80 minutes in order to be certified as ENERGY STAR. The estimated test cycle time does not reflect actual consumer cycle times which vary as a result of load size, dampness, and composition.
Paired clothes dryer ENERGY STAR Model Identifier.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
Type refers to whether the product is a front-loading washer or a top-loading washer.

Connected appliances may or may not enable open-standards connectivity in the home. Consider the following illustrative examples: "Yes" An appliance that can directly communicate using Wi-Fi and OpenADR, or wired Ethernet and SEP 2.x; "No" An appliance that uses proprietary communications to/from the cloud, and is capable of supporting open-standards communications only in the cloud.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

Highly energy efficient heat pump technology typically heats, dehumidifies and circulates air in the dryer drum, so no vent is required. A Heat Pump model solely uses heat pump technology to dry clothes, while a Hybrid Heat Pump model uses a combination of heat pump technology and traditional electric resistance heating technology.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.
This refers to whether the product is intended to be sold in the residential market, the commercial/multi-family housing/coin laundry market, or both.

A unique string of characters used to identify models with the same performance characteristics. This sequence is generated by certification bodies and is reported as a single row of data on the lists of certified products.

IMEF is the energy performance metric for ENERGY STAR certified clothes washers. The higher the IMEF, the more energy efficient the clothes washer. The metric has units: ft3/kWh/cycle, and is calculated as the quotient of the capacity of the clothes container divided by the total clothes washer energy consumption per cycle, with such energy consumption expressed as the sum of the machine electrical energy consumption, the hot water energy consumption, the energy required for removal of the remaining moisture in the wash load, and the combined low-power mode energy consumption. For example, if a clothes washer has a tub volume of 4.0 cubic feet and a total clothes washer energy consumption per cycle of 10 kWh/cycle, then the IMEF is 2.5.

This is the estimated annual water use of the washer under typical conditions. It is based on an annual usage of 295 loads per year, or around 6 loads per week, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J2. Actual water consumption will vary depending on the amount of laundry done.

For combination all-in-one washer-dryers, this is the drum capacity of the clothes dryers in cubic feet as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2. Products with a drum capacity less than 4.4 cubic feet are considered compact.
The width of the product.
Features applicable to the clothes washer may include Steam Cycle, Anti-Wrinkle, Gentle Cycle, Delayed Start, Sanitize Option, Hand Wash Cycle, and Supplementary Wash System.

For combination all-in-one washer-dryers, the cycle selection and settings (temperature and dryness where separately selectable) as defined in the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2, Section 3.3, used for certification to ENERGY STAR.
The mandatory energy efficiency standards for clothes washers, established by DOE rulemaking activities and federal laws.

For combination all-in-one washer-dryers, the Calculated CEF – Max Dry is a measure of the dryer’s energy performance in a more energy consumptive setting, namely the normal cycle with the highest dryness setting as defined in the ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2017 criteria. The Calculated CEF – Max Dry should not be directly compared to the CEF field, which is tested using the medium dryness setting, and represents a rated rather than measured value. The CEF metric has units lbs/kWh and is calculated by dividing the weight of the test load by the sum of the per cycle standby and off mode energy consumption and either the total per-cycle electricity dryer energy consumption or the total per-cycle gas dryer energy consumption expressed in kilowatt hours (kWh).
The mandatory water efficiency standards for clothes washers, established by DOE rule-making activities and federal laws.

For combination all-in-one washer-dryers, features applicable to the clothes dryer may include drum light, wrinkle prevention option, steam cycle, sanitization cycle, filter cleaning indicator, energy monitor/indicator, time remaining display, and supplementary drying system.
Open Standard - Application Layer include SEP 1.x, SEP2.x, OpenADR, etc.
Provides guidance about what you need in your home to enable connected capabilities like smart phone control, e.g. ‘WiFi’ or Zigbee.
The depth of the product.

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as sending notifications when the washer is done or allowing for a service center to remotely diagnose problems. Clothes washers with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill. For combination all-in-one washer-dryer products the washer and dryer must meet connected criteria.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient
Integrated Water Factor (IWF) is a measure of water efficiency that considers gallons of water consumed per cubic foot of capacity. The lower the IWF, the more water efficient the clothes washer.

For combination all-in-one washer-dryers, the estimated annual energy use is based on the Combined Energy Factor and an annual usage of 283 cycles per year, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2. Actual energy consumption will vary on your usage patterns, including how often your run the dryer, what cycle you select, and load size. NOTE: For gas dryers the estimated annual energy use is expressed in kilowatt hours to allow for comparison, and represents the equivalent multi-source energy use of the product (e.g., natural gas or propane typically expressed in British thermal units (Btu)).

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
The height of the product.

This is the estimated annual energy use of the clothes washer under typical conditions, including the energy used by the washer and the energy needed to heat the water used by the clothes washer with an electric water heater. Unlike IMEF, the estimated annual energy use does not address how effective the washer is at removing moisture from the wash load and thus reducing the energy needed to fully dry a load in the clothes dryer. It is based on an annual usage of 295 loads per year, or around 6 loads per week, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J2. Actual energy consumption will vary depending on various factors such as the amount of laundry done, the size of the loads, and the settings chosen.
Indicates if the clothes washer is being marketed as a matched pair with an ENERGY STAR Clothes Dryer.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
This refers to whether the product is a combination all-in-one washer-dryer or laundry center.

columns_description: The sound transmission mechanism of the telephone, either analog, Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP), or a hybrid of analog and VoIP.

A component contained in a separate physical enclosure external to the telephone casing, designed to convert line voltage ac input from the mains to lower dc voltage(s) in order to provide power to the telephone.
A technology which enables reduced power consumption of Fast Ethernet interfaces during times of low data throughput. Specified by IEEE 802.3az.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique

information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will

Frequency ranges are used in cordless telephones primarily to allow for multiple devices to utilize the same ranges and to permit frequency-hopping by the phones. The term “frequency” refers to the rate at which an electromagnetic wave oscillates.

The physical configuration of the telephone including: Cordless Telephone, a telephone with a base station and a handset; Corded Telephone, a telephone with a permanent physical connection between the handset and the network; Conference Telephone, a telephone without a handset that utilizes a speakerphone for all communications and is primarily used for conference calls; Additional Handset, a telephone designed for use with a multi-handset telephone system; or a Wireless (Wi-Fi) Telephone, a telephone that connects via Wi-Fi.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it

An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The number of Fast (10/100) Ethernet ports present in the model.

Mode with the telephone is connected to a power source and a telephone line or other physical or wireless network connection and is capable of receiving a call. The telephone is not receiving or transmitting sound, and the handset is "on the hook" and the speakerphone is not engaged.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
The number of additional handsets supported by the telephone.

The class of Power Over Ethernet indicating the range of operating power of the device. PoE is a technology which enables the transfer of electrical power, along with data, to network end point devices through an Ethernet cable.
The ability of a telephone to maintain network presence on behalf of an End Point Device.
The number of Gigabit (10/100/1000) Ethernet ports present in the model.
A technology which enables reduced power consumption of Gigabit Ethernet interfaces during times of low data throughput. Specified by IEEE 802.3az.
Physical data ports on the model.
The native resolution of the telephone's display.
Low power wireless technologies supported by the model.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
The average water consumption rate of a combination oven operating in steam mode during idle periods expressed in gallons per hour per pan.

The cooking-energy efficiency production capacity of a convection oven or a combination oven operating in convection mode is expressed in pounds per hour. The production rate is the average rate at which the oven brings a specified food product to a specified final temperature.
The number of half-size sheet pans a half-size convection oven can accommodate.
The average water consumption rate of a combination oven operating in convection mode during cooking periods expressed in gallons per pan.
The measured amount of energy an electric oven in convection mode consumes during the pre-heat test.
The average water consumption rate of a convection or rack oven operating in steam injection mode during steam injection periods expressed in gallons per minute.
The number of  full-size sheet pans a full-size convection oven can accommodate.

Designates the size of the commercial convection and combination oven model (but not gas rack ovens), according to the following options for Version 3.0: 1) Full-size convection oven (a convection oven that is able to accomodate standard full-size sheet pans measuring 18 x 26 x 1-inch); 2) Half-size convection oven (a convection oven that is able to accomodate half-sheet pans measuring 18 x 13 x 1-inch); 3) Full-size combination ovens (a combination oven that is able to accomodate two GN 1/1 steam pans measuring 20 3/4 x 12 3/4-inch, per rack or tray position); 4) Half-size combination ovens (a combination oven that is able to accomodate a one GN 1/1 steam pan measuring 20 3/4 x 12 3/4-inch, per rack or tray position); and two-third-size combination ovens (a combination oven that is able to accomodate one GN 2/3 steam pan measuring 13 3/4 x 12 3/4-inch, per rack or tray position). The Version 3.0 specification covers full-size and half-size electric convection ovens; full-size gas convection ovens; full- and half-size electric and gas combination ovens; two-third-size combination ovens.
The measured amount of time an oven requires to pre-heat in convection mode.
The approach used for all ovens to generate steam while operating in steam mode (e.g. boiler/steam generator, boilerless, or spritzer/injector).
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
The average rate of primary energy consumed by gas ovens (i.e., gas is primary heat source for gas ovens).

Designates type of commercial oven model in simple terms as one of the following: electric convection oven, gas convection oven, electric combination oven, gas combination oven, gas single rack oven, or gas double rack oven.
The measured amount of time an oven requires to pre-heat in steam mode.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

The baking-energy efficiency percentage for a rack oven operating in baking mode is the quantity of energy input to the food product (i.e., frozen pies) during the baking process; expressed as a percentage of the quantity of energy input to the oven during the cooking-energy efficiency tests.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The average water consumption rate of a combination oven operating in steam mode during cooking periods expressed in gallons per pan.
The measured amount of energy a gas oven in convection mode consumes during the pre-heat test.

An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. This column includes alternative means to identify the model/model family (e.g., additional model names, additional model numbers, retailer SKUs, product descriptions).

The baking-energy efficiency production capacity of a rack oven operating in baking mode is expressed in pounds per hour. The production rate is the average rate at which the oven brings a specified food product to a specified final temperature.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
The average rate of energy consumed in kW by the electric combination oven operating in steam mode while idling at a ready-to-cook temperature set point.

For ovens with variable Btu/h input, each available input shall be tested individually and meet the cooking energy efficiency and idle energy rate requirements of the specification. The calculated gas or electric oven convection mode idle energy rate value.
The measured amount of energy an electric oven in steam mode consumes during the pre-heat test.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The rack oven has a default setback mode during extended periods of non-use where the oven is idling at a reduced temperature set point.
Gas or electric fuel type.

The date that the model is available for purchase.

The cooking-energy efficiency production capacity of a combination oven operating in steam mode is expressed in pounds per hour. The production rate is the average rate at which the oven brings a specified food product to a specified final temperature.

The cooking-energy efficiency percentage for a combination oven operating in steam mode is the quantity of energy input to the food product (i.e., potatoes) during the cooking process; expressed as a percentage of the quantity of energy input to the oven during the cooking-energy efficiency tests.

The cooking-energy efficiency percentage for an oven operating in convection mode is the quantity of energy input to the food product (i.e., potatoes) during the cooking process; expressed as a percentage of the quantity of energy input to the oven during the cooking-energy efficiency tests.
The average rate of energy consumed in Btu/h by the gas  combination oven operating in steam mode while idling at a ready-to-cook temperature set point.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Light Commercial HVAC
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 4.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Light Commercial HVAC that are effective as of January 1, 2023. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/heating_cooling/light_commercial_heating_cooling/key_product_criteria.
columns_description: Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

The total heating output of a central air-conditioning heat pump during its normal annual usage period for heating, expressed in Btu's and divided by the total electric power input, expressed in Btu/Wh using 10 CFR part 431, Subpart F, §431.96, Table 1.

This column identifies whether the system uses a split system arrangement (remote condensing unit) or a single package system (all components are stored in a single cabinet). All VRF models are required to be listed as "Split System".
The ability of the system to deliver sensible and latent heating when the outside air temperature is 5 F.

The capacity associated with the change in air enthalpy between the air entering the unit and the air leaving the unit, which includes both the latent (change in humidity ratio) and sensible (change in dry-bulb temperature) capacities expressed in Btu/h and include the heat of circulation fan(s) and motor(s).
The ratio of the produced cooling effect of an air conditioner or heat pump to its net work input, expressed in Btu/watt-hour using Proposed Appendix B1 at 86 FR 70316, 70346-70347 (Dec. 9, 2021).

The type of heating section the LCHVAC systems uses. Central air conditioners and heat pumps systems can use either all other heating section types (propane, gas, oil), electric resistance, or none. VRF Multi-Split systems either come with heat recovery or without heat recovery.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
The ratio of the produced cooling effect of an air conditioner or heat pump to its net work input, expressed in Btu/watt-hour using 10 CFR part 431, Subpart F, §431.96, Table 1.
A measure of efficiency in the heating mode that represents the ratio of total heating capacity to electrical energy input, measured at 5 degrees F.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The ability of the system to deliver sensible and latent heating when the outside air temperature is 17 F.

The total heating output of a central air-conditioning heat pump during its normal annual usage period for heating, expressed in Btu's and divided by the total electric power input, expressed in Btu/Wh using Proposed Appendix B1 at 86 FR 70316, 70346-70347 (Dec. 9, 2021).

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification.
